questions.question_text:
A Workspace ONE UEM SaaS environment is no longer synchronizing new users with Active Directory. All configuration settings are correct and the users and groups are mapped properly in the console.
Which integration server should be checked for connectivity issues?

discussion.content: Correct - D - only the ACC has a functionality related to Directory Services and users&group synchronisation.
D is the Answer not B

I think D is the answer because if devices are required to access Exchange online through SEG and SEG encrypts every attachment you are also required to use a Workspace ONE App to decrypt the attachment. You can additionally configure DLP rules to be implemented in the endpoint or App but providing only Box with DLP doesn't cover every risky scenario because information could be potentially accessible through another email agent. I believe SEG with attachment encryption has the most extreme security posture.

choices.C: Native Mail configuration with device pin based encryption

questions.question_text:
A Workspace ONE administrator is configuring email for an organization that uses Microsoft Exchange Online (Office 365). The organization has an extreme security posture and wants to require all email attachments be encrypted.
Which is needed to meet the organization's requirement?
What is the purpose of the Workspace ONE UEM Security Pin?

discussion.content:
Correct: A - https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Workspace-ONE-UEM/2001/UEM_ConsoleBasics/GUID-AWT-SECURITYPIN.html - Security PIN
Establish security for the UEM console by creating a Security PIN. The PIN acts as a safeguard against accidentally wiping a device or deleting important aspects of your environment, such as users and organization groups. The Security PIN also works as a second layer of security. It presents an added point of authentication by blocking actions made by unapproved users.

choices.A: Serves as a second layer of security for administrators while preventing inadvertent commands.
choices.B: Provides multi-factor authentication for users during device enrollment.
choices.C: Provides a second factor of authentication for administrators during console login.
choices.D: Serves as a second layer of security for end users while preventing inadvertent commands.

choices.B: Trigger a background sync on Workspace ONE Boxer.
choices.C: Update the badge count for an unread email.
choices.E: Support most existing corporate file servers.
choices.A: Secure access to internal content repositories.
choices.D: Provide email notification for Exchange mail.

comments.content: Yes, ENS has nothing go do with corporate file servers and content repositories.

questions.question_text: Which three are features of the Email Notification Service? (Choose three.)
Which two are IT-driven on-boarding workflows for Windows 10 devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: OOBE is not IT-driven. Manual staging can be only IT-driven, so correct answers are: A, C

It should be A and C. As per Vmware Textbook. "IT-driven Windows 10 onboarding includes the following methods:
• Command-line interface (CLI) staging 
• Manual device staging 
• Bulk provisioning and enrollment 
• Image-based enrollment 
• Comanagement with SCCM and Workspace ONE UEM"

Selected Answer: AC
I agree it's A and C.

I agree it's A and C. 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Workspace-ONE-UEM/services/Windows_Desktop_Device_Management/GUID-uemWindeskDeviceEnrollment.html#windows-10-device-staging-enrollment-6
"With device staging, you can configure your Windows 10 devices for device management by Workspace ONE UEM before you send the devices to your end users."
"The two staging methods are:

Manual Installation – Download and install the Workspace ONE Intelligent Hub and enter enrollment credentials. This method requires devices to be domain-joined before enrollment.
Command Line Installation – Download the Workspace ONE Intelligent Hub and then install and enroll the device using the command line."
